properties.headline: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert is being issued by Village of Richmound
properties.description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Village of Richmound. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Village of Richmound water system.  This advisory is in effect until further notice.
properties.instruction: Boil water for at least 1 minute prior to use.  This includes for drinking purposes, washing of fruits and vegetables and brushing teeth. Do not drink from any public drinking fountains supplied with water from the public water supply. Use an alternative water source known to be safe.  Listen for updates on the situation.

properties.headline: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert is being issued Resort Village of Manitou Beach
properties.description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Resort Village of Manitou Beach. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Resort Village of Manitou Beach water system.  This advisory is in effect until further notice.
properties.instruction: Boil water for at least 1 minute prior to use.  This includes for drinking purposes, washing of fruits and vegetables and brushing teeth. Do not drink from any public drinking fountains supplied with water from the public water supply. Use an alternative water source known to be safe.  Listen for updates on the situation.

properties.headline: wind warning in effect
properties.description:
Strong easterly wind gusts near 90 km/h are expected to redevelop late this evening and may persist into Saturday morning.

###

Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage.

Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.headline: severe thunderstorm warning in effect
properties.description:
At 5:00 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain.

###

Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
properties.instruction: Lightning kills and injures Canadians every year. Remember, when thunder roars, go indoors!

properties.headline: special weather statement in effect
properties.description:
Heat on tap for the weekend

A heat wave will affect Southern Quebec over the next few days. Daytime highs will be near 30 degrees Celsius while overnight lows will remain above 20. Generally, humidex values will range from 35 to 39 on Saturday and could exceed 40 on Sunday in several parts of Southern Quebec.

The heat may last into Monday.

Reschedule or plan your outdoor activities during the coolest time of the day.
Reduce health risks for young children by frequently cooling them off, keeping them well hydrated and reducing their exposure to the heat.
Plan to visit and check up on loved ones (neighbours, friends and family), especially those who suffer from a loss of autonomy or from a chronic disease, or those who live alone, in order to ensure they are cool and not dehydrated.
If you are taking medication or if you have health issues, ask your doctor or pharmacist if this situation makes you more vulnerable to the heat and follow their recommendations.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.headline: heat warning in effect
properties.description:
A hot and increasingly humid air mass will begin to affect eastern Ontario on Saturday and last through at least Sunday. Cooler and less humid conditions may arrive on Monday.  

Daytime high temperatures: 31 to 34 degrees Celsius 
Overnight low temperatures: 20 to 23 degrees Celsius 
Humidex values: high 30s Saturday increasing to near 40 Sunday

Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category.

###

Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions.

Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
properties.instruction:
Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle.

When it’s hot eat cool, light meals.

Outdoor workers should take regularly scheduled breaks in a cool place.

properties.headline: severe thunderstorm warning in effect
properties.description:
At 3:33 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain.

These thunderstorms are located line from just west of Winnipeg, southward to the US border through Altona and moving east at 70 km/h.

These thunderstorms have a history of nickel to quarter size hail, wind gusts of 90 km/h. As thunderstorms track over the same area they may produce rainfall up to 100 mm.

###

Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
properties.instruction: Lightning kills and injures Canadians every year. Remember, when thunder roars, go indoors!

properties.headline: squall watch in effect
properties.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots this afternoon and early this evening.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
properties.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for potential squalls. Vulnerable vessels are most at risk and should seek safe harbour if underway. Consider delaying or postponing travel in areas under the Squall Watch.

properties.headline: fog advisory in effect
properties.description:
Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring.

Dense fog with visibilities of 400 metres or less persists at Coral Harbour, Naujaat, Igloolik and Hall Beach due to a moist southeasterly flow off Hudson Bay and Foxe Basin. Similar conditions will continue today and tonight, then gradually start to improve on Saturday as winds become lighter and shift more northerly.

###

Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.headline: severe thunderstorm watch in effect
properties.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain this afternoon and early this evening.

Boaters may be surprised by strong wind gusts over bodies of water.

###

Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.headline: frost advisory in effect
properties.description:
Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas.

Minimum temperatures: zero to +2 (coolest in low lying areas).

Locations: most of central, northeastern, and eastern Newfoundland.

Time span: early Saturday morning.

Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as mainly clear skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas.

###

Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
properties.instruction: Cover up plants, especially those in frost-prone areas. Take preventative measures to protect frost-sensitive plants and trees.

properties.headline: severe thunderstorm watch in effect
properties.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain.

Thunderstorms are expected to develop in the foothills this afternoon.  Some of these thunderstorms could become severe.  The severe thunderstorm watch could be expanded to the east in southern Alberta later in the day.

###

Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.headline: severe thunderstorm watch in effect
properties.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain.

A low pressure trough pushing through southern Manitoba today combined with a warm and humid airmass has triggered thunderstorms. Some of these will likely be severe during the late afternoon and evening hours as they track eastward. 

The airmass over portions of western Manitoba has stabilized enough that the watch has been lifted between Dauphin and Melita.

###

Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
properties.instruction: Lightning kills and injures Canadians every year. Remember, when thunder roars, go indoors!

properties.headline: squall watch in effect
properties.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots, frequent lightning and hail.

A low pressure system approaching from SK will allow convective initiation over the Manitoba lakes this afternoon, and these storms will have the risk of strong gusts and damaging hail.

Mariners are advised to prepare for potential squalls. Vulnerable vessels are most at risk and should seek safe harbour if underway.

Consider delaying or postponing travel in areas under the squall watch.

Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury.

Vessels without lightning protection should make their way to shore immediately.

###

Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
properties.instruction: Vessels without lightning protection should make their way to shore immediately. Mariners are advised to prepare for potential squalls. Vulnerable vessels are most at risk and should seek safe harbour if underway. Consider delaying or postponing travel in areas under the Squall Watch.

properties.headline: heat warning in effect
properties.description:
Humidex values reaching 38 are expected for the next 2 days.

A hot and humid air mass will continue to affect the area into Saturday. Slightly cooler and less humid air will arrive on Sunday.

Overnight low temperatures: Near 18 degrees Celsius
Daytime high temperatures: Near 29 degrees Celsius
Humidex values: High 30s

Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category.

###

Extreme heat affects everyone.

Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions.

Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.headline: heat warning in effect
properties.description:
Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next day.

A hot and increasingly humid air mass will affect Gatineau Saturday through at least Sunday. Slightly cooler and less humid conditions may arrive on Monday. 

Daytime high temperatures: 31 to 34 degrees Celsius 
Overnight low temperatures: 20 to 24 degrees Celsius 
Humidex values: high 30s Saturday increasing to low 40s Sunday  

During times of high heat, your health or your family and neighbours' health can deteriorate rapidly. 

The Ministere de la Sante et des services sociaux du Quebec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: 

Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. Follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; avoid alcoholic beverages; if you can, spend at least 2 hours a day in an air-conditioned or cool location; take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; limit physical activity; wear light clothes. 

Be sure to: 

Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
